protocol_name: Optimized protocol for quantification of nitrite levels in brain and head kidney tissue samples in adult zebrafish
protocol_name_html: Optimized protocol for quantification of nitrite levels in brain and head kidney tissue samples in adult zebrafish
description: Zebrafish, and other small teleosts, are used as experimental models to evaluate human pathologies, including those linked to oxidative and nitrosative stress, inflammation, and nitric oxide signaling. The protocol presents an optimized technique to quantify nitrite levels, in zebrafish tissues, focusing on the brain and head kidney. The protocol is based on the classical Griess diazotization reaction (Griess, 1858) method.
before_start: Every biochemical protocol needs to be validated in the laboratory when first introduced. The present protocol describes validation steps that were taken in LaNeC.

materials.reagent_name: Double-bean UV-visible spectrophotometer, with temperature control in the cuvette compartment

warning: Make sure to read all Safety Data Sheets for the reagents. Sulfanilamide is hazardous in case of skin contact (irritant), of eye contact (irritant), of ingestion, and of inhalation. NED causes skin irrtation, serious eye irritation, and may cause respiratory irritation. HCl is very hazardous in case of skin contact, of eye contact, and of ingestion. Therefore, use personal protective equipment whenever manipulating it. Moreover, reagents must be manipulated under a fume hood at all times.
protocol_affiliation: Universidade Federal do Sul e Sudeste do Pará,Universidade do Estado do Pará
affiliation: Universidade Federal do Sul e Sudeste do Pará

authors_list.name: Caio Maximino
authors_list.affiliation: Universidade Federal do Sul e Sudeste do Pará

guidelines: This protocol is intended to quantify nitrite levels in adult zebrafish brain and head kidney tissue samples. It can be adapted for other fish species or other tissues without much hassle; however, tissue amounts may need to be adjusted.
status_info: We use this protocol in our group and it is working

components.data: Data should be entered in two columns, 'x' and 'y', representing concentration and response, respectively. Plot data and perform a linear regression:
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Data should be entered in two columns, 'x' and 'y', representing concentration and response, respectively. Plot data and perform a linear regression:

source_data.name:
if(!require(chemCal)){
   install.packages('chemCal')
   library(chemCal)
}

m <- lm(y ~ x, data = your_data)

summary(m)

calplot(m)
source_data.description: Determine linearity and curve parameters using chemCal for R

components.data: The first step in determining the sensitivity of the assay is to determine the limit of detection (LOD). This can be done using parameters from the linear model, with the function 'lod' from the R package chemCal. Use alpha = 0.01 and beta = 0.5.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The first step in determining the sensitivity of the assay is to determine the limit of detection (LOD). This can be done using parameters from the linear model, with the function 'lod' from the R package chemCal. Use alpha = 0.01 and beta = 0.5.

source_data.name: lod(m, alpha = 0.01, beta = 0.5)
source_data.description: Calculate limit of detection using chemCal for R

components.data: The next step in determining sensitivity of the assay is to determine the limit of quantification (LOQ). This can also be done using parameters from the linear model, with the 'loq' function from the package chemCal. Substitute 'your_n' by the number of technical replicates in the your assay.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The next step in determining sensitivity of the assay is to determine the limit of quantification (LOQ). This can also be done using parameters from the linear model, with the 'loq' function from the package chemCal. Substitute 'your_n' by the number of technical replicates in the your assay.

source_data.name: loq(m, n = your_n)
source_data.description: Determine limit of quantification with the chemCal package

components.data:
Precision refers to the dispersion of measured values around an average value, and its numerical value is determined by the relative standard deviation (RSD):

 

RSD = 100 * s / |x̄|
Where:
s = the sample standard deviation
x̄ = sample mean
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Precision refers to the dispersion of measured values around an average value, and its numerical value is determined by the relative standard deviation (RSD):

 

RSD = 100 * s / |x̄|
Where:
s = the sample standard deviation
x̄ = sample mean

components.data: Intermediate precision, or inter-run precision, defines the precision of a measurement made in the same laboratory made by different analysts and/or different days. We follow ANVISA's recommendations by running three technical replicates for the lowest, intermediate, and highest NaO2 concentrations in two different days and assessing the RSD for each concentration. RSDs higher than 15% indicate low intermediate precision.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Intermediate precision, or inter-run precision, defines the precision of a measurement made in the same laboratory made by different analysts and/or different days. We follow ANVISA's recommendations by running three technical replicates for the lowest, intermediate, and highest NaO2 concentrations in two different days and assessing the RSD for each concentration. RSDs higher than 15% indicate low intermediate precision.

components.data:
Accuracy can be determined after the establishment of linearity, sensitivity, and precision. Run another calibration curve, with at least three technical replicates, for the entire range of concentrations. Accuracy is calculated as the difference between predicted (xi) and measured (xv) absorbances

Predicted values can be obtained based on the linearity curve (Step 1) using a weighted linear model, with weights derived from the curve made for the accuracy determination. Using chemCal (where new_data refers to the curve made for accuracy determination)
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Accuracy can be determined after the establishment of linearity, sensitivity, and precision. Run another calibration curve, with at least three technical replicates, for the entire range of concentrations. Accuracy is calculated as the difference between predicted (xi) and measured (xv) absorbances

Predicted values can be obtained based on the linearity curve (Step 1) using a weighted linear model, with weights derived from the curve made for the accuracy determination. Using chemCal (where new_data refers to the curve made for accuracy determination)

source_data.name:
weights <- with(new_data, {
  yx <- split(y, x)
  ybar <- sapply(yx, mean)
  s <- round(sapply(yx, sd), digits = 2)
  w <- round(1 / (s^2), digits = 3)
})
new_data.means <- aggregate(y ~ x, new_data, mean)

n <- lm(y ~ x, w = weights, data = new_data.means)

inverse.predict(new_data.means, 30, ws = your_weight) #your_weight determined in previous step for 30 μM
inverse.predict(new_data.means, 15, ws = your_weight) #your_weight determined in previous step for 15 μM
inverse.predict(new_data.means, 7.5, ws = your_weight) #your_weight determined in previous step for 7.5 μM
inverse.predict(new_data.means, 3.75, ws = your_weight) #your_weight determined in previous step for 3.75 μM
inverse.predict(new_data.means, 1.875, ws = your_weight) #your_weight determined in previous step for 1.875 μM
inverse.predict(new_data.means, 0.9375, ws = your_weight) #your_weight determined in previous step for 0.9375 μM
inverse.predict(new_data.means, 0.46875, ws = your_weight) #your_weight determined in previous step for 0.46875 μM
inverse.predict(new_data.means, 0.234375, ws = your_weight) #your_weight determined in previous step for 0.234375 μM
source_data.description: Generate predicted values from weighted linear model (weights based on the results from the linearity assay)

components.data:
Use the predicted values xi obtained in the previous step to calculate the accuracy at each level, as:

 

Accuracy = ([xi - xv] / xv) * 100
components.name: Description

source_data.description:

components.data: Sacrifice animal with ice-cold water (< 12 ºC) followed by spinal transection.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Sacrifice animal with ice-cold water (< 12 ºC) followed by spinal transection.

components.data: Carefully dissect the brain (http://dx.doi.org/10.3791/1717) and head kidney (http://dx.doi.org/10.3791/2839).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Carefully dissect the brain (http://dx.doi.org/10.3791/1717) and head kidney (http://dx.doi.org/10.3791/2839).

components.data: Homogenize the tissue samples in 500 μL Zebrafish PBS (0.1 M, pH 7.3). Due to the low sensitivity of the assay, tissues need to be homogenized in a pool from 5 animals.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Homogenize the tissue samples in 500 μL Zebrafish PBS (0.1 M, pH 7.3). Due to the low sensitivity of the assay, tissues need to be homogenized in a pool from 5 animals.

components.data: Correlation coefficients higher than 0.98 suggest linearity. Error residuals should also be checked, looking for deviations in linearity, presence of atypical samples, heteroscedasticity, and dependence between errors; a well-adjusted curve should present erros with a uniform distribution, average zero and constant variance, and absence of atypical samples. An F-test comparing fits of residuals with a linear vs. quadratic model can also be used.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Correlation coefficients higher than 0.98 suggest linearity. Error residuals should also be checked, looking for deviations in linearity, presence of atypical samples, heteroscedasticity, and dependence between errors; a well-adjusted curve should present erros with a uniform distribution, average zero and constant variance, and absence of atypical samples. An F-test comparing fits of residuals with a linear vs. quadratic model can also be used.

components.data: The first step in determining the precision is to assess the repeatability of the assay (that is, intra-run precision). Run three technical replicates for the lowest, intermediate, and highest NaO2 concentrations. Determine intra-run precision by calculating the RSD for each of these concentrations. RSDs higher than 15% indicate low precision.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The first step in determining the precision is to assess the repeatability of the assay (that is, intra-run precision). Run three technical replicates for the lowest, intermediate, and highest NaO2 concentrations. Determine intra-run precision by calculating the RSD for each of these concentrations. RSDs higher than 15% indicate low precision.

components.data:
Nitrite stock solution:

  1. Weight 0.015 g sodium nitrite (NaNO2) and store in a beaker covered in aluminum foil
  2. Dilute in 100 ml distilled water (volume measured in a volumetric flask)
  3. Store in an ambar flask, identified and kept under refrigeration (2 - 8 ºC)
components.name: Description

components.data:
Sulfanilamide stock solution:

  1. Weight 0.5 g sulfanilamide and store in a beaker covered in aluminum foil
  2. Dilute in 100 ml of HCl 20% (volume measured in a volumetric flask)
  3. Store in an ambar flask, identified and kept under refrigeration (2 - 8 ºC)

NED [N-(1-Naphthyl)ethylenediamine] stock solution:

  1. Weight 0.3 g NED and store in a beaker covered in aluminum foil
  2. Dilute in 100 mL HCl 1% (volume measured in a volumetric flask)
  3. Store in an ambar flask, identified and kept under refrigeration (2 - 8 ºC)

source_data.name: inverse.predict(m, unknown_value, alpha = 0.01)
source_data.description:
Interpolate unknowns (sample nitrite) from the calibration curve

m refers to the values derived from the linear model, and unknown_value to the absorbances measured in the assay

components.data: Run a calibration curve by following the steps for linearity (Steps 4-8)
